card.hint: What is the difference between a need and a requirement?

card.question: Explain why (using what you know about human vision) you should not use red text on a blue background.
card.answer: The lens of the human eye can't simultaneously focus wavelengths that are very different from each other.
card.hint: Think about the lens of the human eye (not the cones).

card.question:
Create a UML Use case Diagram for the following partial description of an Internet auction system.

Anyone may use the search features of the system and anyone may look at an auction's information.

Only members (people who are registered with the system) may bid for items or place items for sale. Members must log-in to bid for items or place an item for sale. Members who forget their password can have it mailed to them.
card.hint: Think about the relationship between members and other people.

card.question:

Another possible design of the Professor and Student classes is the following:

Which is better and why?
card.answer: The second design is certainly better. The first design will have considerable code duplication. The second recognizes that both Professor objects and Student objects have something in common -- they are Person objects.
card.hint: When should you use specialization (i.e., create child classes).

card.question: Define the principle of least astonishment as it relates to user interface design and explain why it is a good rule of thumb.
card.answer: It says that you should use consistent terminology, icons, colors, etc... It is motivated by the capacity of working memory and the fact that rehearsal slows decay.
card.hint: Think about the model human processor and, in particular, working memory.
